items.description: Severn Vyrnwy confluence
items.message:
River levels remain high at the Cae Howel river gauge as a result of heavy rain and showers over the last week. Consequently, flooding of roads and farmland is expected to continue. We expect flooding to affect low lying land and roads adjacent to the river from the Welsh border at Llawnt to Shrawardine near Shrewsbury. Other locations that may be affected include Llanymynech, Maesbrook and Melverley. 
At 8am today, Wednesday 05/01/22 the level at the Cae Howel gauge was 4.0m and steady. 
Further rain is forecast over the next few days, meaning we expect river levels to remain high for several more days. We are closely monitoring the situation. Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded. 
This message will be updated 10am on Thursday 06/01/22, or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Lugg south of Leominster
items.message:
River levels remain high at the Lugwardine river gauge as a result of heavy rain and showers over the past week. Consequently, flooding of roads and farmland is expected to continue for the next couple of days. We expect flooding to affect low lying land and roads adjacent to the River Lugg south of Leominster from Stoke Prior to Mordiford. Other locations that may be affected include Bodenham, Lugwardine and Hampton Bishop. Further rain is forecast over the next few days and so we expect river levels to remain high for the next few days. We are closely monitoring the situation. Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded. 
This message will be updated by 10am on Thursday 06/01/22 or if the situation changes.

items.description: Tern and Perry catchments

floodArea.county: Shropshire, Staffordshire, Telford and Wrekin, Wrexham

items.message:
River levels remain high but are falling slowly at the Tern - Walcot river gauge as a result of heavy rainfall and showers over the past week. Consequently, flooding of roads and farmland is expected to continue. We expect flooding to affect low lying land and roads adjacent to the river from Wolverley to Newport. Other locations that may be affected include Market Drayton, Wem and Rodington. River levels will remain high for the next few days, as further rain is forecast over the next few days. We are closely monitoring the situation. Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and avoid contact with flood water.
This message will be updated by 10am on Thursday 06/01/22 or as the situation changes.

items.description: The tidal River Yare from Thorpe St Andrew to Breydon Water
items.message: This message has been issued because some minor flooding to riverside roads and footpaths is possible and will continue through today, Wednesday 5th January, and is expected to stay in force until Friday 7th January. High water levels may last for a few days, until the high tides at Great Yarmouth have passed. This is due to a natural tide locking effect. High tidal water moving up the rivers from Great Yarmouth, is currently restricting the normal drainage out to sea at low tide, of the Broads river system. We expect to see high water levels in Brundall and Reedham riverside areas. Take care on waterside roads and footpaths, and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger. We are monitoring the situation and not expecting the situation to escalate.  We will update this message by 10:00am tomorrow, Thursday 6th January.

items.description: River Ray and its tributaries from Shipton Lee to and including Islip

floodArea.riverOrSea: River Ray, Wootten Brook, Doddershall Brook, Tetchwick Brook, Lugershall Brook, Murswell Hill Brook, Cutters Brook, Piddington Brook, Blackthorn Brook, Panshill Brook, Studley Wood Brook, Beckley Brook, Oddington Brook, Gallos Brook, Chipping Farm Stream

items.message:
Property flooding is not currently expected.
River levels remain high but continue to fall on the lower River Ray following recent rainfall. Therefore, the risk of flooding continues to reduce in the Islip area. 
No further rainfall is forecast this evening, 05/01/22, or into tomorrow morning. River levels are falling, but still pose a flood risk and will be sensitive to further rainfall later this week.
We are closely monitoring the situation.
Please remain safe and aware of your local surroundings and refer to the 'River and Sea levels in England' webpage for current river levels. 
This message will be updated tomorrow morning, 06/01/22, or as the situation changes.

items.description: North Sea coast from Whitby to Filey

floodArea.county: East Riding of Yorkshire, North Yorkshire

items.message: Tides are expected to be higher than usual due to the forecast weather conditions during coming tides. Flooding is possible at the North Sea coast from Whitby to Filey, including Scarborough between 8:15PM and 9:30PM on 05/01/2022. Areas most at risk include low spots around North and South Bay in Scarborough, including the Spa complex. We are expecting higher than normal tides, combined with strong winds which will create large waves over the next 2 days, and as a result we may issue further alerts/warnings. We will continue to monitor the forecast and re-issue this alert if necessary. Please be careful along beaches, promenades, coastal footpaths and roads as large waves and sea spray could be dangerous. This message will be updated by 10:30PM on 05/01/2022, or as the situation changes.

items.description: North Sea coast at Skipsea, Hornsea and Mappleton
items.message: This flood alert has been removed as conditions have eased and tides have fallen below a level of concern. Please see the GOV.UK website for a 5 day flood forecast.

items.description: Lower River Medway
items.eaAreaName: Kent, South London and East Sussex
items.message: River levels are forecast to rise overnight tonight as a result of high tides. Minor flooding of low lying land along the River Medway is expected between 01:15 and 03:15 tomorrow, 06/01/22.  We expect flooding to affect the riverside footpaths in the Maidstone area from Lock Meadow to Allington Lock. River levels are expected to peak in Maidstone after high tide at 02:15. We are closely monitoring the situation and our incident response staff are prepared to respond if required. Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses. Please remain aware of your local situation. This message will be updated tomorrow morning, 06/01/22, or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Thame and Chalgrove Brook
items.message:
Property flooding is not currently expected.
River levels remain high but are generally falling on the River Thame following recent rainfall. Therefore, flooding of low-lying land, footpaths and roads is expected to continue, especially in the Thame area. 
No further rainfall is forecast this evening, 05/01/22, or into tomorrow morning. River levels are falling, but still pose a flood risk and will be sensitive to further rainfall later this week.
We are closely monitoring the situation. Our incident response staff have been in the area clearing weed/trash screens. 
Please remain safe and aware of your local surroundings and refer to the 'River and Sea levels in England' webpage for current river levels. 
This message will be updated tomorrow morning, 06/01/22, or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Trent from Cromwell Weir to Gainsborough
items.message:
This Flood Alert has now been removed.  
River and high tide levels have now fallen below the flood risk threshold.  There is no longer a threat of flooding, though standing water and debris may still remain.  
We continue to monitor the situation.

items.description: Christchurch Harbour
items.message: This Flood Alert has been removed. Peak tide levels are expected to be lower for the remainder of the week. We will continue to monitor the forecast and will re-issue this alert if necessary.

items.message: Tides are expected to be higher than usual due to the forecast weather conditions during coming tides. Flooding is possible at the North Sea coast at Withernsea, Easington and Kilnsea between 6:45PM and 09:15PM on 05/01/2022. Areas most at risk include low spots around Kilnsea and Spurn Point. We are expecting higher than normal tides over the next 2 days and as a result we may issue further alerts/warnings. We will continue to monitor the forecast and re-issue this alert if necessary. Please be careful along beaches, promenades, coastal footpaths and roads as large waves and sea spray could be dangerous. This message will be updated by 9:00PM on 05/01/2022, or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Thames at Trowlock Island
items.message:
Property flooding is not currently expected. River levels forecast to rise on the River Thames tonight at Trowlock Island due to the high tide. We are closely monitoring the situation. Our incident response staff are closing the Thames Barrier. The next high tide tomorrow (06/01/22) is forecast to be below the flood alert threshold.
Please refer to the 'River and Sea levels in England' web page for current river levels,  and see the GOV.UK website for a 5 day flood forecast. This message will be updated tomorrow, 06/01/2022, or earlier if the situation changes.

items.description: Severn estuary from Gloucester to Sharpness
items.message:
A series of high tides is due in the Severn Estuary until Wednesday evening the 5/1/22. Flooding may affect low lying land and roads adjacent to the Severn Estuary from Sandhurst to Chepstow and Sharpness. High tides may also affect watercourses draining into the Severn Estuary. 
Predicted peaks:- Sandhurst 2.9m to 3.3m at 23:45 on 05/01/22, flooding is not expected in other gauge locations.
Sandhurst 3.0m to 3.4m at 12:00 on 06/01/22, flooding is not expected in other gauge locations.

We are closely monitoring the situation. Our incident response staff are checking defences.
Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses.  
This message will be updated by 17:00 on 06/01/22, or if the situation changes.

items.description: North Sea coast from Staithes to Whitby including tidal River Esk
items.message: Tides are expected to be higher than usual due to the forecast weather conditions during coming tides. Flooding is possible at the North Sea coast from Staithes to Whitby including Sandsend and tidal River Esk between 7:45PM and 9:00PM on 05/01/2022. Areas most at risk include low spots around Sandsend, Staithes Harbour and Whitby Harbour New Quay Road. We are expecting higher than normal tides over the next 2 days and as a result we may issue further alerts/warnings. We will continue to monitor the forecast and re-issue this alert if necessary. Please be careful along beaches, promenades, coastal footpaths and roads as large waves and sea spray could be dangerous. This message will be updated by 9:00PM on 05/01/2022, or as the situation changes.

items.description: The north Norfolk coast from Old Hunstanton, to and including Cley
items.message: This message has been issued because some minor flooding to coastal roads and footpaths is likely between 7:15pm and 9:15pm on Wednesday 5th January. Tides are expected to be higher than usual, due to forecast weather conditions during spring tides. We expect to see water on roads and paths to beaches and on the quays in Brancaster, Burnham Overy, Holkham, Wells and Blakeney. The detailed forecast for those that use it is for a peak level at Wells of 3.77 mAODN at 8:15pm, Wednesday 5th January, which is 0.69m above tide tables, wind Force 6, north-westerly. (mAODN is height above average sea level, for more info refer to local tide tables). Take care on coastal roads and footpaths, and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger. We are monitoring the situation and will keep you updated of the flood risk.  We will update this message by 7:30am Thursday 6th January.

Tides are expected to be higher than usual, due to forecast weather conditions during spring tides. We may see water on Beach Road at Cley, and Beach Road at Salthouse, and footpaths in the marshes may also become inaccessible. The detailed forecast for those that use it is for a peak level at Wells of 3.77 mAODN at 8:15pm, Wednesday 5th January, which is 0.69m above tide tables, wind Force 6, north-westerly. (mAODN is height above average sea level, for more info refer to local tide tables). Take care on coastal roads and footpaths, and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger. We expect to see high water levels in Lake Lothing in Lowestoft as well as high sea levels along the Suffolk Coast, impacting on beach access points. The detailed forecast for those that use it is for a peak level at Lowestoft of 1.86 mAODN at 11pm tonight, Wednesday 5th January, which is 0.73m above tide tables, wind Force4, north-westerly. (mAODN is height above average sea level, for more info refer to local tide tables).  Take care on coastal roads and footpaths, and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger. We are monitoring the situation and will keep you updated of the flood risk.  We will update this message by 10am tomorrow, Thursday 6th January.

items.description: Coast from Ramsgate to Kingsdown
items.eaAreaName: Kent, South London and East Sussex
items.message: High tides are expected to continue to affect the foreshore from Ramsgate to Kingsdown tomorrow, Thursday 06/01/22, as a result of high spring tides and strong winds. Tides will be at their highest between 00:45 and 01:15 tomorrow, Thursday 06/01/22, with high tide at 01:00. Flooding to roads and low lying land is expected at these times, however these conditions may apply two to four hours either side of high tide. We expect flooding to affect coastal areas, particularly low lying land and roads nearest the sea. Coastal conditions are expected to improve after the high tide at 01:15 on 06/01/22. We are closely monitoring the situation and our incident response staff are prepared to respond if required. Please be careful along beaches, promenades, coastal footpaths as large waves and sea spray could be dangerous. This message will be updated tomorrow morning, Thursday 06/01/22, or as the situation changes. Please remain aware of your local situation. For those that use it, the astronomical water level will be 3.05m AOD and the total water level will be 3.60m AOD.

Flooding to roads and low lying land is expected at these times, however these conditions may apply two to four hours either side of high tide. Tide levels will now be dropping away to neaps and no impacts are expected after today. There may still be some areas where flood water is present until it can naturally drain away. Continue to take care on waterside roads and footpaths, and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger. We will continue to monitor levels closely.

items.description: Riverside properties along the tidal River Yare including Cantley, Brundall and Reedham
items.message: This message has been issued because flooding of homes and businesses still remains likely. The higher water levels will continue through this evening into tomorrow, Thursday 6th January, and the flood warning is expected to stay in force for the next few tides. A flood Alert remains in force for the wider area. High water levels may last for a few days, until the high tides at Great Yarmouth have passed. This is due to a natural tide locking effect. High tidal water moving up the rivers from Great Yarmouth, is currently restricting the normal drainage out to sea at low tide, of the Broads river system. Areas most at risk are in Reedham, Cantley and Brundall. Roads affected include Ferry Road in Reedham, the A47 and the railway line between Reedham and Brundall.  Take care on waterside roads and footpaths. We are monitoring the situation and will update messages when necessary.  We will update this message by 10am tomorrow, Thursday 6th January.

Our incident response staff are closing the Thames Barrier. The next high tide tomorrow (06/01/22) is forecast to be below the flood alert threshold.
Please refer to the 'River and Sea levels in England' web page for current river levels, and see the GOV.UK website for a 5 day flood forecast. This message will be updated tomorrow, 06/01/2022, or earlier if the situation changes.

items.description: The tidal River Stour at Mistley
items.message: Levels are now below the flood risk thresholds. Continue to take care on waterside roads and footpaths, and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger. We will continue to monitor levels closely.

items.description: The tidal River Orwell at Cliff Quay industrial area in Ipswich
items.message: Levels are now below the flood risk thresholds. Continue to take care on waterside roads and footpaths, and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger. We will continue to monitor levels closely.

items.description: Tyne and Wear coast

floodArea.county: County Durham, Hartlepool, North Tyneside, South Tyneside, Sunderland

items.message: This flood alert has been removed. The risk of flooding from strong winds and high tides at Seaham, Seaburn, Hendon Promenade and Whitley Bay has now reduced. For a 5 day flood risk forecast please see the GOV.UK website or for a weather forecast see the Met Office website.

items.description: Hartlepool to Cowbar

floodArea.county: Hartlepool, North Yorkshire, Redcar and Cleveland

items.message: This flood alert has been removed. The risk of flooding from strong winds and high tides along the Hartlepool to Cowbar coast has now reduced. No further overtopping and spray is expected. For a 5 day flood risk forecast please see the GOV.UK website or for a weather forecast see the Met Office website.

For a 5 day flood risk forecast please see the GOV.UK website or for a weather forecast see the Met Office website.
